trans-unit.source: Consume an internal API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client
trans-unit.target: Consume an internal API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client

trans-unit.source: Learn how to consume an API app from a .NET API app in the same resource group, using the App Service SDK.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to consume an API app from a .NET API app in the same resource group, using the App Service SDK.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to write code for an ASP.NET API app that calls another API app configured for Internal access level.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to write code for an ASP.NET API app that calls another API app configured for Internal access level.

trans-unit.source: Both API apps must be in the same resource group.
trans-unit.target: Both API apps must be in the same resource group.

trans-unit.source: The same code can be used to call an internal API app from a <linkText>mobile app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The same code can be used to call an internal API app from a <linkText>mobile app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You'll build a ContactNames Web API.
trans-unit.target: You'll build a ContactNames Web API.

trans-unit.source: The Web API's Get method will call a ContactsList API app and return just the names out of the contact information provided by the ContactsList API app.
trans-unit.target: The Web API's Get method will call a ContactsList API app and return just the names out of the contact information provided by the ContactsList API app.

trans-unit.source: Here's the Swagger UI screen for a successful call to the ContactNames Get method.
trans-unit.target: Here's the Swagger UI screen for a successful call to the ContactNames Get method.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to call API apps that are configured for Public (anonymous) or Public (authenticated) access levels, see Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to call API apps that are configured for Public (anonymous) or Public (authenticated) access levels, see Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial assumes that you are familiar with how to create projects and add code to them in Visual Studio, and how to <linkText>manage API apps in the Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial assumes that you are familiar with how to create projects and add code to them in Visual Studio, and how to <linkText>manage API apps in the Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The project and code samples in this article are based on the API app project that you create and deploy in these articles:
trans-unit.target: The project and code samples in this article are based on the API app project that you create and deploy in these articles:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already done so, follow the <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorial to deploy the ContactsList sample project to an API app in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already done so, follow the <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorial to deploy the ContactsList sample project to an API app in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, in the API app blade for the ContactsList API app that you deployed earlier, click Settings > Application Settings and set Access level to Internal, and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, in the API app blade for the ContactsList API app that you deployed earlier, click Settings > Application Settings and set Access level to Internal, and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create an API app project named ContactNames by using the Azure API app project template.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create an API app project named ContactNames by using the Azure API app project template.

trans-unit.source: This is the same process that you followed in <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title>, but you'll add different code to the project later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This is the same process that you followed in <linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title>, but you'll add different code to the project later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: The following steps are explained in more detail in <linkText>Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The following steps are explained in more detail in <linkText>Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and select Add > Azure API App Client.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and select Add > Azure API App Client.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Azure API App Client dialog, click Download from Azure API App.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Azure API App Client dialog, click Download from Azure API App.

trans-unit.source: From the drop-down list, select the API app that you want to call.
trans-unit.target: From the drop-down list, select the API app that you want to call.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial choose the ContactsList API app that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial choose the ContactsList API app that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: By default, API App projects are enabled with automatic <linkText>Swagger</linkText><title>Official Swagger information</title> metadata generation, but the Azure API App new-project template disables the API test page.
trans-unit.target: By default, API App projects are enabled with automatic <linkText>Swagger</linkText><title>Official Swagger information</title> metadata generation, but the Azure API App new-project template disables the API test page.

trans-unit.source: In this section you enable the test page.
trans-unit.target: In this section you enable the test page.

trans-unit.source: Open the App_Start/SwaggerConfig.cs file, and search for EnableSwaggerUI:
trans-unit.target: Open the App_Start/SwaggerConfig.cs file, and search for EnableSwaggerUI:

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the following lines of code:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the following lines of code:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Controllers folder, and select Add > Controller.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Controllers folder, and select Add > Controller.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Scaffold dialog, select the Web API 2 Controller - Empty option, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Name the controller ContactNamesController, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Name the controller ContactNamesController, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: To call an API app that has been protected by setting its access level to Internal, you have to add internal authentication headers to HTTP requests.
trans-unit.target: To call an API app that has been protected by setting its access level to Internal, you have to add internal authentication headers to HTTP requests.

trans-unit.source: These headers inform the target API app that the source of the call is a peer API app calling from within the same resource group.
trans-unit.target: These headers inform the target API app that the source of the call is a peer API app calling from within the same resource group.

trans-unit.source: The App Service SDK generates client classes that simplify the code you write to call API app.
trans-unit.target: The App Service SDK generates client classes that simplify the code you write to call API app.

trans-unit.source: To call a Public (anonymous) API app all you have to do is create a client object and call methods on it, as in this example:
trans-unit.target: To call a Public (anonymous) API app all you have to do is create a client object and call methods on it, as in this example:

trans-unit.source: However, to add authentication headers you need access to the HttpRequestMessage object and you don't have that here.
trans-unit.target: However, to add authentication headers you need access to the HttpRequestMessage object and you don't have that here.

trans-unit.source: To get access to the request and add the headers you have to create a DelegatingHandler class and pass in an instance of it to the constructor of the generated client.
trans-unit.target: To get access to the request and add the headers you have to create a DelegatingHandler class and pass in an instance of it to the constructor of the generated client.

trans-unit.source: Add to the project a class file named InternalCredentialHandler.cs, and replace the template code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Add to the project a class file named InternalCredentialHandler.cs, and replace the template code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This code calls SignHttpRequest to add the authentication headers to every request sent by the generated client class:
trans-unit.target: This code calls SignHttpRequest to add the authentication headers to every request sent by the generated client class:

trans-unit.source: In ContactNamesController.cs, replace the template code with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In ContactNamesController.cs, replace the template code with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This code passes in the handler to the constructor of the generated client class:
trans-unit.target: This code passes in the handler to the constructor of the generated client class:

trans-unit.source: You can't test by running locally.
trans-unit.target: You can't test by running locally.

trans-unit.source: You have to deploy the code and run it in an Azure API app; otherwise you won't be able to add the right authentication headers, and the calls will be rejected.
trans-unit.target: You have to deploy the code and run it in an Azure API app; otherwise you won't be able to add the right authentication headers, and the calls will be rejected.

trans-unit.source: The following deployment steps are explained in more detail in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The following deployment steps are explained in more detail in <linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Create a ContactNames API app.
trans-unit.target: Create a ContactNames API app.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and click Publish.

trans-unit.source: Click the Profile tab, and then click Microsoft Azure API Apps.
trans-unit.target: Click the Profile tab, and then click Microsoft Azure API Apps.

trans-unit.source: Click New to provision a new API App in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click New to provision a new API App in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In the Create an API App dialog, enter ContactNames as the API App Name.
trans-unit.target: In the Create an API App dialog, enter ContactNames as the API App Name.

trans-unit.source: For the other values in the Create an API App dialog, enter the same values that you entered earlier for the Deploy an API app.
trans-unit.target: For the other values in the Create an API App dialog, enter the same values that you entered earlier for the Deploy an API app.

trans-unit.source: Most importantly, make sure you create the new API app in the same resource group as the API app you're going to call.
trans-unit.target: Most importantly, make sure you create the new API app in the same resource group as the API app you're going to call.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Deploy your code to the new API app.
trans-unit.target: Deploy your code to the new API app.

trans-unit.source: Once the API app is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and click Publish to re-open the publish dialog.
trans-unit.target: Once the API app is provisioned, right-click the project in Solution Explorer and click Publish to re-open the publish dialog.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish Web dialog, click Publish to begin the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish Web dialog, click Publish to begin the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: In this section you use the Swagger UI to test the new API app and verify that it can call the API app you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: In this section you use the Swagger UI to test the new API app and verify that it can call the API app you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser to the new API app's URL.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser to the new API app's URL.

trans-unit.source: With the default publish settings, when Visual Studio completes the publish process it automatically opens a browser to the URL of the API app.
trans-unit.target: With the default publish settings, when Visual Studio completes the publish process it automatically opens a browser to the URL of the API app.

trans-unit.source: If that doesn't happen, or you have closed that browser window, follow these steps to get to the same URL:
trans-unit.target: If that doesn't happen, or you have closed that browser window, follow these steps to get to the same URL:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App blade for the new ContactsName API app.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API App blade for the new ContactsName API app.

trans-unit.source: Click URL.
trans-unit.target: Click URL.

trans-unit.source: In the browser address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL, and press Enter.
trans-unit.target: In the browser address bar, add /swagger to the end of the URL, and press Enter.

trans-unit.source: For example, the resulting URL will look like this:
trans-unit.target: For example, the resulting URL will look like this:

trans-unit.source: In the Swagger UI page, click ContactNames > Get > Try it out!
trans-unit.target: In the Swagger UI page, click ContactNames > Get > Try it out!

trans-unit.source: The page displays contact names in the Response Body section, which verifies that the ContactNames API app successfully retrieved data from the ContactsList API app.
trans-unit.target: The page displays contact names in the Response Body section, which verifies that the ContactNames API app successfully retrieved data from the ContactsList API app.

trans-unit.source: If you want to verify that the Internal setting is protecting the ContactsList API app, comment out the SignHttpRequest call in ContactNamesController.cs, redeploy, run Swagger Try it now again, and you'll get an error message.
trans-unit.target: If you want to verify that the Internal setting is protecting the ContactsList API app, comment out the SignHttpRequest call in ContactNamesController.cs, redeploy, run Swagger Try it now again, and you'll get an error message.

trans-unit.source: The App Service SDK depends on Swagger API definitions to generate client classes.
trans-unit.target: The App Service SDK depends on Swagger API definitions to generate client classes.

trans-unit.source: If you want to call an API app that has not implemented Swagger API definitions, you can do so using HttpClient.
trans-unit.target: If you want to call an API app that has not implemented Swagger API definitions, you can do so using HttpClient.

trans-unit.source: In this case, you still use the SignHttpRequest method, but you call it directly on the HttpRequestMessage object.
trans-unit.target: In this case, you still use the SignHttpRequest method, but you call it directly on the HttpRequestMessage object.

trans-unit.source: In ContactNamesController.cs, add the following code before the return names; statement in the Get method.
trans-unit.target: In ContactNamesController.cs, add the following code before the return names; statement in the Get method.

trans-unit.source: This code passes in the incoming request object to the SignHttpRequest method to sign the outgoing request object:
trans-unit.target: This code passes in the incoming request object to the SignHttpRequest method to sign the outgoing request object:

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API app blade for the ContactsList API app, and copy the URL.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, go to the API app blade for the ContactsList API app, and copy the URL.

trans-unit.source: Replace the placeholder string "{yourapiappurl}" in the controller code with the actual URL.
trans-unit.target: Replace the placeholder string "{yourapiappurl}" in the controller code with the actual URL.

trans-unit.source: When you're done, that line of code will look like the following example.
trans-unit.target: When you're done, that line of code will look like the following example.

trans-unit.source: Follow the same procedure you did earlier to deploy the API app code.
trans-unit.target: Follow the same procedure you did earlier to deploy the API app code.

trans-unit.source: Hint: You can bypass the Publish Web dialog and redeploy by clicking a single button in the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: Hint: You can bypass the Publish Web dialog and redeploy by clicking a single button in the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, click View > Toolbars, and enable the Web One Click Publish toolbar.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, click View > Toolbars, and enable the Web One Click Publish toolbar.

trans-unit.source: Follow the procedure you did earlier to use the Swagger UI.
trans-unit.target: Follow the procedure you did earlier to use the Swagger UI.

trans-unit.source: Since you left in the HttpClient code, the output this time shows a duplicate set of names.
trans-unit.target: Since you left in the HttpClient code, the output this time shows a duplicate set of names.

trans-unit.source: This article has shown how to consume an internal API app from a .NET client.
trans-unit.target: This article has shown how to consume an internal API app from a .NET client.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to consume API apps that are set to Public (authenticated) and Public (anonymous) access levels, see Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to consume API apps that are set to Public (authenticated) and Public (anonymous) access levels, see Consume an API app from a .NET client in Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: For additional examples of code that calls an API app from .NET clients, download the <linkText>Azure Cards</linkText><title></title> sample application.
trans-unit.target: For additional examples of code that calls an API app from .NET clients, download the <linkText>Azure Cards</linkText><title></title> sample application.

trans-unit.source: For information about authentication in App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about authentication in App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
